elements.content: This contribution describes the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic implementation of the highly constrained molybdenum­(VI) polymers [MoO2(LR)] n (with R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)) and cyclic tetramer [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 ­·0.5MeCN (3′·0.5MeCN) with nicotinoyl hydrazonato ligands (LR) derived from salicylaldehyde (LH), 3-methoxy-2-hydroxybenaldehyde (L3OMe), or 4-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (L4OMe). In order to determine the most stable geometries, conformational analysis of the free and coordinated ligands in these assemblies was carried out through the potential energy surface scans using quantum-chemical methods. The mononuclear analogues [MoO2(HLR)­(MeOH)]Cl (R = H (1a) and 3OMe (2a)), [MoO2(HLR)­Cl] (R = 3OMe (2b) and 4OMe (3b)), and [MoO2(LR)­(MeOH)] (R = H (1c), and 4OMe (3c-α and 3c-β)) were also synthesized and evaluated as potential precursors for reactions in the solid state. Vapor induced transformation of 2a quantitatively afforded complex 2b. The chemometric analysis using principal component analysis was applied to provide insight into the reaction profile. Thermally induced solid-state reactions resulted in the transformation of metallocycle 3′·0.5MeCN and monomeric complexes 1c, 2a, 3c-α, and 3c-β into the corresponding coordination polymers. The structural features responsible for these conversions are discussed in detail. Lastly, the metallosupramolecular architectures were tested as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation by using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as an oxidant in water or decane. Compound 3′ is shown to be the most effective and selective catalyst.
elements.clean_text: This contribution describes the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic implementation of the highly constrained molybdenum(VI) polymers [MoO2(LR)] n  (with R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)) and cyclic tetramer [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 ⋅0.5MeCN (3'⋅0.5MeCN) with nicotinoyl hydrazonato ligands (LR) derived from salicylaldehyde (LH), 3-methoxy-2-hydroxybenaldehyde (L3OMe), or 4-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (L4OMe). In order to determine the most stable geometries, conformational analysis of the free and coordinated ligands in these assemblies was carried out through the potential energy surface scans using quantum-chemical methods. The mononuclear analogues [MoO2(HLR)(MeOH)]Cl (R = H (1a) and 3OMe (2a)), [MoO2(HLR)Cl] (R = 3OMe (2b) and 4OMe (3b)), and [MoO2(LR)(MeOH)] (R = H (1c), and 4OMe (3c-α and 3c-β)) were also synthesized and evaluated as potential precursors for reactions in the solid state. Vapor induced transformation of 2a quantitatively afforded complex 2b. The chemometric analysis using principal component analysis was applied to provide insight into the reaction profile. Thermally induced solid-state reactions resulted in the transformation of metallocycle 3'⋅0.5MeCN and monomeric complexes 1c, 2a, 3c-α, and 3c-β into the corresponding coordination polymers. The structural features responsible for these conversions are discussed in detail. Lastly, the metallosupramolecular architectures were tested as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation by using tert-butyl hydroperoxide as an oxidant in water or decane. Compound 3' is shown to be the most effective and selective catalyst.

elements.content: This contribution describes the synthesis, characterization, and catalytic implementation of the highly constrained Mo­(VI) polymers and cyclic tetramer with nicotinoyl hydrazonato ligands. Solid-state reactivity and structural modification involving tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes driven by exposure to solvent vapors and heat we also discuss by means of chemometrics and quantum chemical calculations.

Solid-state reactivity and structural modification involving tetranuclear and mononuclear complexes driven by exposure to solvent vapors and heat we also discuss by means of chemometrics and quantum chemical calculations.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, self-assembly of metallosupramolecular architectures has been the focus of intensive research due to the wide range of applications of these assemblies in various fields. A large number of compounds of versatile chemical composition and structure have been prepared and investigated. For this purpose, functional bridging ligands (e.g., pyridine or carboxylate-based ligands) with different spacer groups between donor atoms have been used. Nevertheless, self-assembled structures containing only polydentate ligands are also possible.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few decades, self-assembly of metallosupramolecular architectures has been the focus of intensive research due to the wide range of applications of these assemblies in various fields. A large number of compounds of versatile chemical composition and structure have been prepared and investigated. For this purpose, functional bridging ligands (e.g., pyridine or carboxylate-based ligands) with different spacer groups between donor atoms have been used. Nevertheless, self-assembled structures containing only polydentate ligands are also possible.

elements.content: Metallosupramolecular architectures are commonly prepared via solution-based synthesis, but they can also be attained in the solid state. Generally, reactions and transformations in the solid state are more difficult than in solution as they involve new bond formation or breakage with restricted molecular movements. Therefore, reactivity in the solid state is a consequence of molecular assemblies within crystals, and such transformations are expected to occur only between suitably arranged molecules with reactive functional groups close to each other. The external stimuli that usually promote such conversions are heat, solvent vapors, mechanochemical force, light, etc.
elements.clean_text: Metallosupramolecular architectures are commonly prepared via solution-based synthesis, but they can also be attained in the solid state. Generally, reactions and transformations in the solid state are more difficult than in solution as they involve new bond formation or breakage with restricted molecular movements. Therefore, reactivity in the solid state is a consequence of molecular assemblies within crystals, and such transformations are expected to occur only between suitably arranged molecules with reactive functional groups close to each other. The external stimuli that usually promote such conversions are heat, solvent vapors, mechanochemical force, light, etc.

elements.content: Metal–ligand assemblies involving polydentate organic molecules and cis-MoO2 2+ units have been explored scarcely. Up to now, several studies have resulted in the synthesis of interesting compounds of the general formula [MoO2(L)] x , (x = 2, 4, 6, or n, and L = aroylhydrazone) and {[MoO2(L′)]4} z– (L′ = 2,3,7-trihydroxyfluor-6-one), with unique crystal structures featuring molecular squares, hexagons, and zigzag chains. It is apparent that such materials can utilize the advantages of organic molecules for the fine-tuning of their structures and consequently their properties. Accordingly, recent results have demonstrated that macrocyclic dinuclear Mo­(VI) complexes with hemilabile ligands L have encouraging potential as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation under environmentally friendly reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text: Metal-ligand assemblies involving polydentate organic molecules and cis-MoO2 2+ units have been explored scarcely. Up to now, several studies have resulted in the synthesis of interesting compounds of the general formula [MoO2(L)] x , (x = 2, 4, 6, or n, and L = aroylhydrazone) and {[MoO2(L')]4} z-  (L' = 2,3,7-trihydroxyfluor-6-one), with unique crystal structures featuring molecular squares, hexagons, and zigzag chains. It is apparent that such materials can utilize the advantages of organic molecules for the fine-tuning of their structures and consequently their properties. Accordingly, recent results have demonstrated that macrocyclic dinuclear Mo(VI) complexes with hemilabile ligands L have encouraging potential as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation under environmentally friendly reaction conditions.

elements.content: Herein we report a successful approach of architectural design strategy and synthesis of geometrically constrained metallosupramolecular-based architectures [MoO2(L)] x , (x = n, 4) with aroylhydrazone ligands, salicylaldehyde (H2LH), 3-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (H2L3OMe), and 4-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde nicotinoyl hydrazone (H2L4OMe) (Scheme S1 in the Supporting Information). We describe the effect of different variables affecting the final product formation and stability of compounds depending on the coordinative restraints generated by the ligand and metal coordination sphere. We show that in the solid state, crystalline mononuclear compounds can be transformed via vapor or thermally induced reactions. The change of structural parameters responsible for the solid-state reactivity and noncovalent interactions that induce the final compound formation are discussed in detail. Conversions induced by external stimuli we also discuss by means of chemometrics and quantum chemical calculations.

We describe the effect of different variables affecting the final product formation and stability of compounds depending on the coordinative restraints generated by the ligand and metal coordination sphere. We show that in the solid state, crystalline mononuclear compounds can be transformed via vapor or thermally induced reactions. The change of structural parameters responsible for the solid-state reactivity and noncovalent interactions that induce the final compound formation are discussed in detail. Conversions induced by external stimuli we also discuss by means of chemometrics and quantum chemical calculations.

elements.content: To complement these studies, new catalysts based on the MoO2 2+ building blocks presented herein were tested for catalytic cyclooctene epoxidation by using tert-butyl hydroperoxide, and the effectiveness of different supramolecular isomers was evaluated.

elements.content: A series of reactions between [MoO2Cl2] and the corresponding ligand H2LR (Scheme S1) in methanol yielded coordination polymers and monomers depending on the reaction conditions ( and Scheme S2 in the Supporting Information). Thus, the solvothermal synthesis at 110 °C resulted in the formation of single crystals of [MoO2(LR)] n , with R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3), (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Compound 1 is the second polymorph of this compound (form I can be found in CCDC, code ZILVOH). Whereas the analogous reactions carried out with H2L3OMe or H2L4OMe at lower temperatures yielded monomers [MoO2(HL3OMe)­(MeOH)]Cl (2a, at 5 °C) or [MoO2­(HL3OMe or 4OMe)­Cl] (2b or 3b, at room temperature), the reaction with H2LH resulted mainly in the formation of 1 even at −5 °C. A very small amount of the [MoO2(HLH)­(MeOH)]Cl (1a) sufficient only for single crystal X-ray diffraction experiment was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solution-Based Synthesis

Halide Ligand Exchange Reactions

A series of reactions between [MoO2Cl2] and the corresponding ligand H2LR (Scheme S1) in methanol yielded coordination polymers and monomers depending on the reaction conditions ( and Scheme S2 in the Supporting Information). Thus, the solvothermal synthesis at 110 °C resulted in the formation of single crystals of [MoO2(LR)] n , with R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3), (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Compound 1 is the second polymorph of this compound (form I can be found in CCDC, code ZILVOH). Whereas the analogous reactions carried out with H2L3OMe or H2L4OMe at lower temperatures yielded monomers [MoO2(HL3OMe)(MeOH)]Cl (2a, at 5 °C) or [MoO2(HL3OMe or 4OMe)Cl] (2b or 3b, at room temperature), the reaction with H2LH resulted mainly in the formation of 1 even at -5 °C. A very small amount of the [MoO2(HLH)(MeOH)]Cl (1a) sufficient only for single crystal X-ray diffraction experiment was obtained.

elements.content:
Blue arrows indicate reactions performed in organic solvents. Green and red arrows represent vapor and thermally induced solid-state transformations, respectively.

Acetylacetonate Ligand Exchange Reactions

The reaction of [MoO2(acac)2] with H2LH under solvothermal conditions in EtOH at 110 °C yielded single crystals of [MoO2(LH)] n (1), Scheme S2 in the Supporting Information. The analogous synthesis in MeOH gave complex [MoO2(LH)­(MeOH)] (1c) no matter which reaction condition was chosen, and no evidence of 1 or ZILVOH was detected (powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Polymers [MoO2(L3OMe or 4OMe)] n (2–3) were obtained from reactions carried out with H2L3OMe or H2L4OMe in methanol or acetonitrile under reflux or at room temperature, but each time they were isolated as crystalline powders. Efforts have been made to obtain the cyclic isomer by changing the concentration of the acetonitrile solution. Thus, complexation of cis-MoO2 2+ with H2L4OMe carried out in a very dilute solution resulted in the formation of the cyclic tetramer [MoO2(L4OMe)]4­·0.5MeCN (3′·0.5MeCN), .

Acetylacetonate Ligand Exchange Reactions

The reaction of [MoO2(acac)2] with H2LH under solvothermal conditions in EtOH at 110 °C yielded single crystals of [MoO2(LH)] n  (1), Scheme S2 in the Supporting Information. The analogous synthesis in MeOH gave complex [MoO2(LH)(MeOH)] (1c) no matter which reaction condition was chosen, and no evidence of 1 or ZILVOH was detected (powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Polymers [MoO2(L3OMe or 4OMe)] n  (2-3) were obtained from reactions carried out with H2L3OMe or H2L4OMe in methanol or acetonitrile under reflux or at room temperature, but each time they were isolated as crystalline powders. Efforts have been made to obtain the cyclic isomer by changing the concentration of the acetonitrile solution. Thus, complexation of cis-MoO2 2+ with H2L4OMe carried out in a very dilute solution resulted in the formation of the cyclic tetramer [MoO2(L4OMe)]4⋅0.5MeCN (3'⋅0.5MeCN), .

elements.content: A mixture of the polymorphic forms [MoO2(L4OMe)­(MeOH)] (3c-α and 3c-β) was also obtained through direct reaction of the starting reagents at 10 °C in methanol, , whereas 3c-α was prepared as the only product in the second reaction carried out upon the addition of seed crystals. Polymorph 3c-β was obtained in pure form only by the deprotonation of 3b with Et3N in MeOH. A comparison of PXRD patterns was used to identify these forms in the bulk sample (). The reaction of 2b with Et3N proceeds differently, and the coordination polymer 2 was obtained without isolation of the corresponding monomer. It is expected that the deprotonation reaction leads to the formation of a labile intermediate complex with the coordinated methanol molecule, which is then displaced by the nicotinoyl part of the neighboring molecule.

elements.content: All complexes are identified by strong bands in the range 890–900 cm–1 and 920–930 cm–1 characteristic for ν­(MoO2) vibrations. The absorption bands belonging to CNimine and C–Ophenolic groups (at 1603–1614 cm–1 and 1232–1289 cm–1, respectively) are also present in the spectra of all of the complexes. Absence of the bands characteristic for the N–H and CO groups in spectra of MoO2(LR)] n (R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)), [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 (3′), and [MoO2(LR)­(MeOH)] (R = H (1c), and 4OMe (3c-α and 3c-β)) indicates the hydrazone tautomerism (N–NH–(CO)– → N–N(C–OH)−), deprotonation, and coordination through the oxygen atom. This is also supported by the presence of a new band at ca. 1340 cm–1 assigned to the C–O group of the hydrazone moiety. Formation of the Mo–Nnicotinyl bond in 1–3 is additionally supported by the absence of a broad band at ∼850 cm–1 characteristic of an intermolecular MoO···Mo interaction. A band around 1050 cm–1 seen in the IR spectra of 1c and 3c is assigned to the C–OMeOH stretching vibration.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Characterization

All complexes are identified by strong bands in the range 890-900 cm-1 and 920-930 cm-1 characteristic for ν(MoO2) vibrations. The absorption bands belonging to CNimine and C-Ophenolic groups (at 1603-1614 cm-1 and 1232-1289 cm-1, respectively) are also present in the spectra of all of the complexes. Absence of the bands characteristic for the N-H and CO groups in spectra of MoO2(LR)] n  (R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)), [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 (3'), and [MoO2(LR)(MeOH)] (R = H (1c), and 4OMe (3c-α and 3c-β)) indicates the hydrazone tautomerism (N-NH-(CO)- → N-N(C-OH)-), deprotonation, and coordination through the oxygen atom. This is also supported by the presence of a new band at ca. 1340 cm-1 assigned to the C-O group of the hydrazone moiety. Formation of the Mo-Nnicotinyl bond in 1-3 is additionally supported by the absence of a broad band at ~850 cm-1 characteristic of an intermolecular MoO⋅⋅⋅Mo interaction. A band around 1050 cm-1 seen in the IR spectra of 1c and 3c is assigned to the C-OMeOH stretching vibration.

elements.content: In [MoO2(HL3OMe)­(MeOH)]Cl (2a), [MoO2(HL3OMe)­Cl] (2b), and [MoO2­(HL4OMe)­Cl] (3b), the ligands are found to be in the singly deprotonated form (HL)− coordinated to the cis-MoO2 2+ core via the ONO donor atoms. The band characteristic for the CO group at ca. 1650 cm–1 (seen in the IR spectra of H2L) is shifted to 1545–1556 cm–1 in the spectra of the complexes, suggesting coordination of hydrazidato ligand through the carbonyl oxygen atom.
elements.clean_text: In [MoO2(HL3OMe)(MeOH)]Cl (2a), [MoO2(HL3OMe)Cl] (2b), and [MoO2(HL4OMe)Cl] (3b), the ligands are found to be in the singly deprotonated form (HL)- coordinated to the cis-MoO2 2+ core via the ONO donor atoms. The band characteristic for the CO group at ca. 1650 cm-1 (seen in the IR spectra of H2L) is shifted to 1545-1556 cm-1 in the spectra of the complexes, suggesting coordination of hydrazidato ligand through the carbonyl oxygen atom.

elements.content:
Compounds were further characterized also by NMR spectroscopy (see this section in the Supporting Information).

Crystal and Molecular Structures

Molecular and crystal structures of all complexes have been determined from the single crystal X-ray diffraction data (, Figures S3–S6 in the Supporting Information). Selected crystallographic and refinement data for structures are reported in Table S1 (Supporting Information). In all the molecular structures, the Mo atom displays a slightly distorted octahedral coordination involving a N and two O atoms from a hydrazone acting as a tridentate ligand and two O atoms from the cis-MoO2 2+ unit. The sixth coordination place is occupied with the O atom from a methanol molecule, chloride, or N atom from the pyridine moiety of the neighboring ligand molecule (, Figure S5 in the Supporting Information).

Crystal and Molecular Structures

Molecular and crystal structures of all complexes have been determined from the single crystal X-ray diffraction data (, Figures S3-S6 in the Supporting Information). Selected crystallographic and refinement data for structures are reported in Table S1 (Supporting Information). In all the molecular structures, the Mo atom displays a slightly distorted octahedral coordination involving a N and two O atoms from a hydrazone acting as a tridentate ligand and two O atoms from the cis-MoO2 2+ unit. The sixth coordination place is occupied with the O atom from a methanol molecule, chloride, or N atom from the pyridine moiety of the neighboring ligand molecule (, Figure S5 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Like in almost all cis-dioxomolybdenum coordination compounds, the Mo atom is not in the center of the octahedron but is shifted toward the axial atoms. The distance from the plane defined by O1, O2, O3, and N1 ranges from 0.2987(4) (in 1) to 0.3598(5) Å (in 3′·0.5MeCN). Because of that, nonplanar five- and six-membered chelate rings are inclined posing ligand molecules in nonplanar conformations (1 and 3 are relatively planar in comparison with others). In all the complexes, the Mo–O distances within the cis-MoO2 2+ unit are the shortest ones, as expected, indicating that they are double bonds (Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Additionally, cis-MoO2 2+ bond angles are significantly larger than regular ones, indicating greater repulsion between O atoms closely bound to the Mo atom. Coordination of the Mo atom by the sixth donor atom is weaker which is reflected in the lengthening of the Mo–O5 (N3 or Cl1) distances ().
elements.clean_text: Like in almost all cis-dioxomolybdenum coordination compounds, the Mo atom is not in the center of the octahedron but is shifted toward the axial atoms. The distance from the plane defined by O1, O2, O3, and N1 ranges from 0.2987(4) (in 1) to 0.3598(5) Å (in 3'⋅0.5MeCN). Because of that, nonplanar five- and six-membered chelate rings are inclined posing ligand molecules in nonplanar conformations (1 and 3 are relatively planar in comparison with others). In all the complexes, the Mo-O distances within the cis-MoO2 2+ unit are the shortest ones, as expected, indicating that they are double bonds (Table S2 in the Supporting Information). Additionally, cis-MoO2 2+ bond angles are significantly larger than regular ones, indicating greater repulsion between O atoms closely bound to the Mo atom. Coordination of the Mo atom by the sixth donor atom is weaker which is reflected in the lengthening of the Mo-O5 (N3 or Cl1) distances ().

If we orientate ligand molecules in the same way (equatorial plane atoms O1, N1, O2, and O3 arranged clockwise; N3 atom on the left side, ) some interesting features will come out. In complexes 1, 2, 3b, 3c-α, and 3′·0.5MeCN, Mo atoms are below the plane defined by O1, N2, O2, and O3 atoms, while in others the Mo atoms are above the same plane (, ). In tetramer 3′·0.5MeCN, one Mo atom is above and the other is below the equatorial plane. The trans-configuration of the N2 atoms with respect to N3 is observed in almost all cases where the Mo atom is above (six out of seven), while cis-configuration is found in four out of five cases in which the Mo atom is below the equatorial plane.

elements.content: Besides the grouping of the complexes by ligand type, they can be categorized according to the role of the N3 atom. If N3 is protonated, as it is in 3b, 1a, 2b, and 2a, then the overall charge is balanced by the presence of chloride, either as a free or coordinating ion. In chloride salts, 1a and 2a chloride ions act as a bifurcated hydrogen bond acceptor (N3–H3N and O5–H5O are donors) forming infinite chains parallel to the crystallographic c axis [graph set notation C 1 2(10)], Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information. In 2a and 3b, Cl1 participates in hydrogen bonds of C 1 1(8) type, parallel to the crystallographic c and a axes, respectively. If the N3 atom is not protonated, then it can be coordinated to the Mo atom from neighboring molecules, thus forming coordination polymers 1–3 or cyclic tetramer 3′·0.5MeCN.

In chloride salts, 1a and 2a chloride ions act as a bifurcated hydrogen bond acceptor (N3-H3N and O5-H5O are donors) forming infinite chains parallel to the crystallographic c axis [graph set notation C 1 2(10)], Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information. In 2a and 3b, Cl1 participates in hydrogen bonds of C 1 1(8) type, parallel to the crystallographic c and a axes, respectively. If the N3 atom is not protonated, then it can be coordinated to the Mo atom from neighboring molecules, thus forming coordination polymers 1-3 or cyclic tetramer 3'⋅0.5MeCN.

elements.content: The fingerprint plots based on Hirshfeld surfaces for the polymorphic forms 3c-α and 3c-β are shown in . Long sharp spikes correspond to hydrogen bonds O5–H···N3 (middle spike corresponds to H···H interaction). The most interesting difference between the plots is the existence of the pair of wings in 3c-β (the first centered around 2.8 Å, the second at 3.5 Å). Further analysis showed a significant difference in C···C interactions which contribute 0.8% in 3c-α compared to 4.6% in 3c-β.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that 1 is a polymorph of this compound (form I, CSD code ZILVOH). Although both polymorphs crystallize in the same non-centrosymmetric space group (P212121), their packing is slightly different (Figure S7, fingerprints in the Supporting Information) and their basic units differ in curvedness (Figure S7, right column in the Supporting Information). In ZILVOH, the Mo atom is above the plane defined in the previous paragraph (while in 1 it is below).

elements.content: On the basis of distinct behavior of complexes in solution, we were interested in the possibility of the intrasolid ligand exchange at the metal center upon exposure of the monomeric complexes to solvent vapors. Crystals of [MoO2(HL3OMe)­(MeOH)]­Cl (2a) without grinding were exposed to solvent vapors (water, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, and i-propanol) in several independent sets. The sample of each set was taken out after a certain period and was immediately analyzed ex situ by attenuated total reflection-infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). As indicated by PXRD, , the counterion-mediated ligand exchange occurred and complex [MoO2(HL3OMe)­Cl] (2b) was obtained as the final product no matter which solvent was used. It should be noted that the formation of liquid phases was not observed during experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Reactivity and Structural Transformations

Vapor Induced Desolvation Reactions and Structural Transformations

On the basis of distinct behavior of complexes in solution, we were interested in the possibility of the intrasolid ligand exchange at the metal center upon exposure of the monomeric complexes to solvent vapors. Crystals of [MoO2(HL3OMe)(MeOH)]Cl (2a) without grinding were exposed to solvent vapors (water, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, and i-propanol) in several independent sets. The sample of each set was taken out after a certain period and was immediately analyzed ex situ by attenuated total reflection-infrared (ATR-IR) spectroscopy (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). As indicated by PXRD, , the counterion-mediated ligand exchange occurred and complex [MoO2(HL3OMe)Cl] (2b) was obtained as the final product no matter which solvent was used. It should be noted that the formation of liquid phases was not observed during experiments.

elements.content: In order to provide insight into the reaction profiles, principal component analysis (PCA) was applied to analyze ATR spectra obtained by reaction monitoring (Figure S8, in the Supporting Information). As seen from and , a different exposure time was necessary to complete this transformation depending on the solvent polarity and protic nature of the solvent. The fastest transformation was in the case of water vapor (3 h), whereas the slowest one was in dichloromethane vapor (48 h).

Together with the acetonitrile (24 h), a linear correlation with the dielectric constant of the solvent can be established, Figure S9 in the Supporting Information. In the case of i-propanol, taking into account the dielectric constant of solvent, a shorter exposure time was obtained. elements.content: Each MeOH ligand in 2a forms hydrogen-bonding interactions with the Cl– ligand, and the shortest nonbonded Mo···Cl distance is found to be 4.57 Å. Upon vapor exposure, the coordinated MeOH ligand is lost, and the coordination sphere is re-established by the adjacent Cl– ligand. For this transformation, the Cl– anion moves to 2.79 Å. This change involves formation/breaking of coordination and hydrogen bonds, and thereby formation of 2b.

elements.content: It should be noted that compound [MoO2(LH)­(MeOH)] (1c) converts into the coordination polymer [MoO2(LH)] n (1), upon exposure to solvent vapors, but this transformation is very slow to be followed as described for 2a. The analogous transformation of 3c-α or 3c-β into polymer 3 is even significantly slower than transformation to 1. In comparison to chains of molecules in 1c, the crystal structure of both 3c polymorphs consists of supramolecular dimers (all H-bond acceptors and donors are coordinatively saturated, i.e., O5–H5···N3) which could be the reason for the slower reaction.

elements.content: We were interested in the thermally promoted structural rearrangements of 1c, 3c-α, and 3c-β in the solid state. Initially, the stability of these compounds was investigated. The crystals of the monomers are stable in dry air at room temperature. They were found to crack after losing MeOH upon heating (in the range 134–164 °C (1c), 141–165 °C (3c-α), and 116–147 °C (3c-β)). Afterward, the nonsolvated products decomposed at 350, 330 and 339 °C, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Thermally Induced Aggregation Reactions and Structural Transformations

We were interested in the thermally promoted structural rearrangements of 1c, 3c-α, and 3c-β in the solid state. Initially, the stability of these compounds was investigated. The crystals of the monomers are stable in dry air at room temperature. They were found to crack after losing MeOH upon heating (in the range 134-164 °C (1c), 141-165 °C (3c-α), and 116-147 °C (3c-β)). Afterward, the nonsolvated products decomposed at 350, 330 and 339 °C, respectively.

elements.content: In the next experiment the crystalline samples of 1c, 3c-α, and 3c-β were heated at 250 °C for 1 h, and the obtained products were examined by PXRD (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). Upon removal of the coordinated solvents by heating, the vacant coordination sites at Mo­(VI) centers were replenished by the N-donor atom of the nicotinoyl moiety from a neighboring unit resulting in [MoO2(LR)] n (R = H in 1 and R = 4OMe in 3, respectively), . Formation of 1 and 3 can be explained by the coordination of the favorably oriented neighboring building units. The distance between Mo and Nnicotinoyl, which were linked during rearrangement, changed from 4.31 to 2.47 Å (in 1c → 1), 4.56 to 2.50 Å (in 3c-α → 3), 4.09 to 2.50 Å (in 3c-β → 3), . Also in this type of transformation the nitrogen atoms in monomeric complexes which were hydrogen bonded to the MeOH ligand now bridged Mo­(VI) centers to form chains of 1 and 3.

Also in this type of transformation the nitrogen atoms in monomeric complexes which were hydrogen bonded to the MeOH ligand now bridged Mo(VI) centers to form chains of 1 and 3.

elements.content: Close inspection of crystal structures of 1c, 1, and ZILVOH reveals some interesting observations. Taken altogether, it seems that the transformation of 1c to 1 is easier to accomplish. Upon the egress of methanol molecules the monomeric unit needs to be translated to form the Mo1–N3 bond, while in hypothetical 1c to ZILVOH transformation, the monomeric unit must be translated and rotated to achieve a proper position in the final polymeric structure.

elements.content: In the case of the cyclic isomer 3′·0.5CH 3 CN, at 80 °C, the structure collapses irreversibly upon partial removal of the guest molecules. Thermal extrusion of acetonitrile molecules at 250 °C for 1 h led to a ring opening polymerization and formation of 3 (). The proposed mechanism for the conversion involves Mo–N (nicotinoyl) bond cleavage/reformation.

elements.content: In the case of [MoO2(HL3OMe)­(MeOH)]­Cl (2a), two steps were noticed due to MeOH (152–170 °C) and HCl (198–237 °C) loss. On heating desolvation and dehydrochlorination led to the transformation of 2a into 2b (at 160 °C) and 2 (at 220 °C), respectively. The obtained products were examined by PXRD (Figure S11 in the Supporting Information). On the contrary, thermogravimetric (TG) study of [MoO2­(HL4OMe)­Cl] (3b) complex revealed that release of a HCl molecule was accompanied by the decomposition of the ligand without formation of a stable intermediate. Therefore, this compound could not be used for thermally induced solid-state reactions.

elements.content: To quantify and predict the crystal packing of investigated compounds, we calculated the one-dimensional (1D) potential for the rotation of pyridine ring. This potential was obtained for the free ligands Figure S12 in the Supporting Information, and then for the ligand in the surroundings of the crystal packing. As expected, variations in the structure of ligand do not have a significant influence on the potential of pyridine ring rotation in the free ligand, and Figure S13a,b in the Supporting Information. But these variations were significant when the crystal packing was included, and Figures S13b,c and S14b in the Supporting Information. The barriers are becoming much higher thus ensuring the orientation of the nitrogen atom toward molybdenum and reducing the possible ways in which the crystal packing is made.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculation

To quantify and predict the crystal packing of investigated compounds, we calculated the one-dimensional (1D) potential for the rotation of pyridine ring. This potential was obtained for the free ligands Figure S12 in the Supporting Information, and then for the ligand in the surroundings of the crystal packing. As expected, variations in the structure of ligand do not have a significant influence on the potential of pyridine ring rotation in the free ligand,  and Figure S13a,b in the Supporting Information. But these variations were significant when the crystal packing was included,  and Figures S13b,c and S14b in the Supporting Information. The barriers are becoming much higher thus ensuring the orientation of the nitrogen atom toward molybdenum and reducing the possible ways in which the crystal packing is made.

elements.content: In addition, the profile of 1D potential in tetrameric structure (c) shows consistently higher values of electronic energy than polymeric structure (b). The first local minimum in 3′ is positioned at 136.26 kJ mol–1 above the global minimum, whereas the equivalent structure in 3 is at 87.13 kJ mol–1. Close inspection of the crystal structures revealed that the steric hindrance with the methyl groups in 3′ is responsible for this kind of behavior. Moreover, in 3 there is a certain type of energy plateau present from 150° to 250° (b) which allows easier arrangement of the rotated pyridine ring. This higher potential spanned along the curve makes the whole structure more constrained in the tetramer. To confirm these findings, models of tetramer and polymer (with 4 units) were constructed, and geometry optimization was carried out. Calculated standard Gibbs energies of formation were 20.75 kJ mol–1 higher in the case of tetramer, also proving the fact that the tetramer structure is in the tenser environment than in the polymer. Additionally, longer bond distances Mo–Npy and calculated structure constraint in 3′ could contribute to easier catalytic sites formation and better overall catalytic activity of 3′ (see part).

Moreover, in 3 there is a certain type of energy plateau present from 150° to 250° (b) which allows easier arrangement of the rotated pyridine ring. Additionally, longer bond distances Mo-Npy and calculated structure constraint in 3' could contribute to easier catalytic sites formation and better overall catalytic activity of 3' (see  part).

Barriers for ring rotation are significantly higher in the case of the polymorph ZILVOH. These higher barriers mean that the crystal packing is denser, thus providing the surrounding which has a bigger electrostatic influence on the rotation of the ring.

elements.content: Complexes [MoO2LR] n (R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)) and [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 (3′) were tested as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation. The oxidizing agent tert-butyl hydroperoxide, TBHP, was used either in the aqueous solution or in decane, in order to compare the influence of the solvent used for the oxidant delivery. It has to be pointed out that no other organic solvents were added to the reaction mixture. In all the experiments, Mo loading was 0.25%, emphasizing quite low catalyst loading. Catalysts 1–3 and 3′ are much more soluble in the reaction media when using TBHPdecane than TBHPaq. IR spectra of the starting compounds and the compounds recovered after the catalytic reaction, using TBHPaq, are presented in Figure S15, in the Supporting Information, showing the complex stability.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Studies

Complexes [MoO2LR] n  (R = H (1), 3OMe (2), and 4OMe (3)) and [MoO2(L4OMe)]4 (3') were tested as catalysts for cyclooctene epoxidation. The oxidizing agent tert-butyl hydroperoxide, TBHP, was used either in the aqueous solution or in decane, in order to compare the influence of the solvent used for the oxidant delivery. It has to be pointed out that no other organic solvents were added to the reaction mixture. In all the experiments, Mo loading was 0.25%, emphasizing quite low catalyst loading. Catalysts 1-3 and 3' are much more soluble in the reaction media when using TBHPdecane than TBHPaq. IR spectra of the starting compounds and the compounds recovered after the catalytic reaction, using TBHPaq, are presented in Figure S15, in the Supporting Information, showing the complex stability.

elements.content: Generally seen, the catalysts perform a higher activity in all the reactions with the use of TBHP in decane, 66–99%. However, when using aqueous TBHP, cyclooctene conversion reaches the value of 27–78%. Selectivity toward cyclooctene epoxide in TBHPaq varies 45–85%, while in TBHPdecane is 78–94%. All the obtained data are reported in .

Catalytic Results for the Cyclooctene Epoxidation by TBHP in Water and in Decane<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref> comp TBHP in: conv /% selec/% TON TOF20 min 1 water 36 45 151 116 2 27 56 113 72 3 49 67 192 119 3′ 78 85 204 151 1 decane 66 78 273 225 2 74 85 305 200 3 79 87 324 221 3′ 99 94 397 1152

It can be concluded that the presence of water negatively affects the catalytic activity of Mo systems 1–3, and as expected, the presence of decane increases all catalytic performances in comparison with water. It could be thought at first glance that decane does give a positive contribution to the overall system (compared to water) and . The most pronounced solvent effect is presented for the metallocyclic compound 3′, for which TOF20 min value with the TBHPdecane, increases almost 8 times, showing very fast catalyst activation, reaching its maximum after only 20 min of the reaction start. The decane certainly helps the catalytic system in two directions. First, according to the mechanism postulated previously, the compounds must have the sixth coordination sphere free to let the approach of TBHP and then the transfer of oxygen from TBHP to olefin. Water can be in coordination competition with TBHP (as it has been proven with other type of solvents) and could for instance lower the reactivity. In decane, where no water is present, this competition does not occur and the system does act faster. The second role of decane is certainly a solvent one since the complexes are soluble in TBHP in decane, favoring the catalytic cycle.

elements.content: In summary, the metallosupramolecular architectures 1–3 and 3′ containing the cis-MoO2 2+ cores with the linker group being the nicotinoyl part of the ligand have been obtained in organic media. Their formation in solution can be controlled by temperature, concentration, or medium polarity. The solid-state reactivity of the mononuclear compounds 2a, 1c, and 3c and mutual modifications into 2b, 1, and 3, respectively, are primarily influenced by removal of solvents and/or rearrangement of bonds. They occur only if the reacting groups of the molecules are close and in the favorable orientation for the reaction to occur in the solid state. The rearrangements of the molecules are additionally controlled by the interplay of the intermolecular interactions, and these are in turn related to differences in the reactivity induced by solvent vapors. Additionally, the exclusive formation of the polymer via thermally induced reactions in the solid state is consistent with the preference for its formation at high concentrations of building units. Furthermore, the constrained local environment promotes reaction selectivity in the solid state, as seen in the case for 1 and ZILVOH.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the metallosupramolecular architectures 1-3 and 3' containing the cis-MoO2 2+ cores with the linker group being the nicotinoyl part of the ligand have been obtained in organic media. Their formation in solution can be controlled by temperature, concentration, or medium polarity. The solid-state reactivity of the mononuclear compounds 2a, 1c, and 3c and mutual modifications into 2b, 1, and 3, respectively, are primarily influenced by removal of solvents and/or rearrangement of bonds. They occur only if the reacting groups of the molecules are close and in the favorable orientation for the reaction to occur in the solid state. The rearrangements of the molecules are additionally controlled by the interplay of the intermolecular interactions, and these are in turn related to differences in the reactivity induced by solvent vapors. Additionally, the exclusive formation of the polymer via thermally induced reactions in the solid state is consistent with the preference for its formation at high concentrations of building units. Furthermore, the constrained local environment promotes reaction selectivity in the solid state, as seen in the case for 1 and ZILVOH.

elements.content: According to quantum chemical calculations, the tetranuclear structure is less stable than the polymeric one. In comparison to polymeric constrained geometry catalysts, the tetranuclear catalyst displays enhanced activity and produces predominantly cyclooctene epoxide. The positioning of the pyridyl–nitrogen, longer Mo–Npy bond distances, and structural constraints in tetramer could be the cause of the better overall catalytic activity.

elements.content: Ligands were prepared by the reaction of nicotinoyl hydrazide with an appropriate aldehyde according to the procedures described in the literature. Salicylaldehyde, 3-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde, 4-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde, and nicotinoyl hydrazide were commercially available. The starting compounds [MoO2(acac)2] and [MoO2Cl2] were prepared as described in the literature. All compounds were characterized by IR spectroscopy and thermal and elemental analyses (data are given in the Supporting Information). Compounds were further characterized by NMR spectroscopy (Scheme S3, Table S3, and Figures S16 and S17, in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthetic Procedures

Ligands were prepared by the reaction of nicotinoyl hydrazide with an appropriate aldehyde according to the procedures described in the literature. Salicylaldehyde, 3-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde, 4-methoxy-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde, and nicotinoyl hydrazide were commercially available. The starting compounds [MoO2(acac)2] and [MoO2Cl2] were prepared as described in the literature. All compounds were characterized by IR spectroscopy and thermal and elemental analyses (data are given in the Supporting Information). Compounds were further characterized by NMR spectroscopy (Scheme S3, Table S3, and Figures S16 and S17, in the Supporting Information).

A mixture prepared by adding [MoO2(acac)2] (0.1 g, 0.31 mmol) to the solution of H2L4OMe·H2O (0.09 g, 0.31 mmol) in 135 mL of acetonitrile was heated at 50 °C for 3 h. After filtration, the crystals for TG measurement were quickly transferred on a dry filter paper into a desiccator and then placed in a freezer (at −15 °C) in order to prevent loss of MeCN molecules. elements.content: In a typical reaction, cyclooctene (2.76 mL, 20 mmol), aqueous TBHP (70% w/w, 40 mmol) or TBHP in decane (5.5 mol dm–3, 40 mmol) and acetophenone (0.1 mL) and molybdenum (pre)­catalyst, 1–3 or 3′ (0.05 mmol), were used, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 80 °C. The reaction was monitored by withdrawing small aliquots at certain time intervals and analyzing them by GC.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the Epoxidation of Cyclooctene by TBHP (in Water or Decane)

In a typical reaction, cyclooctene (2.76 mL, 20 mmol), aqueous TBHP (70% w/w, 40 mmol) or TBHP in decane (5.5 mol dm-3, 40 mmol) and acetophenone (0.1 mL) and molybdenum (pre)catalyst, 1-3 or 3' (0.05 mmol), were used, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 80 °C. The reaction was monitored by withdrawing small aliquots at certain time intervals and analyzing them by GC.

elements.content: Elemental analyses were provided by the Analytical Services Laboratory of the Ruđer Bošković Institute, Zagreb. TG analyses were carried out with a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851e thermobalance using aluminum crucibles. All experiments were recorded in a dynamic atmosphere of oxygen with a flow rate of 200 cm3 min–1. Heating rates of 5 K min–1 were used for all investigations. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two FTIR spectrometer using the ATR technique. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance III HD 400 spectrometer operating at 400 MHz. Compounds were dissolved in DMSO-d 6 and measured in 5 mm NMR tubes at 298 K with TMS as an internal standard. The sample concentration was 10 mg/mL.

elements.content: Good quality single crystals of all compounds were grown from the corresponding mother liquids at room temperature. Diffracted intensities were collected on Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur 3 diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scans. Data were prepared using the CrysAlis1 program package. A summary of general and crystal data, intensity data collection, and final refinement parameters are presented in Table S1. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program. The refinement procedure by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 values against all reflections included anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms except in the 3′·0.5MeCN, where the disordered acetonitrile molecule was refined isotropically. The same molecule was modeled using a negative PART number (because it was near the inversion center). The restraints on geometrical and displacement parameters (DFIX and ISOR) were applied for that molecule. All refinements were performed using SHELXL-97. The SHELX programs operated within the WinGX3 suite. Geometrical calculations and molecular graphics were done with PARST, PLATON, MERCURY, and Crystal Explorer.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography. Single Crystal Diffraction

Good quality single crystals of all compounds were grown from the corresponding mother liquids at room temperature. Diffracted intensities were collected on Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur 3 diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using ω-scans. Data were prepared using the CrysAlis1 program package. A summary of general and crystal data, intensity data collection, and final refinement parameters are presented in Table S1. The structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program. The refinement procedure by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 values against all reflections included anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-H atoms except in the 3'⋅0.5MeCN, where the disordered acetonitrile molecule was refined isotropically. The same molecule was modeled using a negative PART number (because it was near the inversion center). The restraints on geometrical and displacement parameters (DFIX and ISOR) were applied for that molecule. All refinements were performed using SHELXL-97. The SHELX programs operated within the WinGX3 suite. Geometrical calculations and molecular graphics were done with PARST, PLATON, MERCURY, and Crystal Explorer.

elements.content: Conformational search for all compounds was performed by calculation of complete potential energy surfaces (PES). PES were spanned by relevant torsional coordinates around single bonds in the relative range of 0–360° starting from the initial structure. PES scans were obtained by varying the torsional coordinates using the automatic conformational generator implemented in program qcc. For each torsional coordinate the step size was 10° thus giving a total number of 2985984 (six coordinates) or 248832 (five coordinates) single point calculations for each compound. Calculations of PES were conducted at the PM6 semiempirical level of the theory. Data from PES scans were arranged in an n-way array. Parallelized combinatorial optimization algorithm for the arbitrary number of ways (dimensions) implemented in program moonee was used to determine all local minimums on the investigated PES. All local minimums were reoptimized at the B3LYP/6-31G­(d) level of the theory. To ensure that the obtained geometries were local minimums, harmonic frequency calculations were performed. The standard Gibbs energies were calculated at T = 298.15 K and p = 101325 Pa. Strengths of intramolecular bonds were estimated by subtraction of standard Gibbs energies. All quantum-chemical calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculation

Conformational search for all compounds was performed by calculation of complete potential energy surfaces (PES). PES were spanned by relevant torsional coordinates around single bonds in the relative range of 0-360° starting from the initial structure. PES scans were obtained by varying the torsional coordinates using the automatic conformational generator implemented in program qcc. For each torsional coordinate the step size was 10° thus giving a total number of 2985984 (six coordinates) or 248832 (five coordinates) single point calculations for each compound. Calculations of PES were conducted at the PM6 semiempirical level of the theory. Data from PES scans were arranged in an n-way array. Parallelized combinatorial optimization algorithm for the arbitrary number of ways (dimensions) implemented in program moonee  was used to determine all local minimums on the investigated PES. All local minimums were reoptimized at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level of the theory. To ensure that the obtained geometries were local minimums, harmonic frequency calculations were performed. The standard Gibbs energies were calculated at T = 298.15 K and p = 101325 Pa. Strengths of intramolecular bonds were estimated by subtraction of standard Gibbs energies. All quantum-chemical calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 program.

elements.content: Chemometrical analyses were performed using the second-order tensor decomposition tool principal component analysis, PCA. In PCA, the data matrix with mean-centered columns X of rank r is decomposed as a sum of r matrices t i p i τ of rank 1. PCA enables one to find the best linear projections for a high dimensional set of data in the least-squares sense. Scores t i represent projections of the original sample points on the principal component (PC) direction and can be used for classification or building of probability distributions. Therefore, each point in score plots represents one sample ATR spectra. Loadings p i τ represent the eigenvectors of data covariance (or correlation) matrix and can be used for the identification of variability among the data. In this case the physical units of principal components loadings are the same as the intensity units in ATR spectra. The initial development of PCA goes back to Beltrami and Pearson, whereas the name was introduced by Hotelling. More details on PCA can be found in the literature. Principal component analysis was used as a dimensionality reduction tool and performed using a NIPALS algorithm implemented in our own program moonee.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(HL<sup>3OMe</sup>)­Cl] (<bold>2b</bold>)

Ligand H2L3OMe·H2O (0.11 g, 0.38 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (30 mL). [MoO2Cl2] (0.075 g, 0.38 mmol) was added to the solution and left at room temperature. After several days an orange product was filtered and dried. Yield: 40 mg, 24.5%. [MoO2(HL4OMe)­Cl] (3b). The complex was prepared in the same manner as 2a using [MoO2Cl2] and H2L4OMe·H2O. Yield: 100 mg, 61.1%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>H</sup>)­(MeOH)] (<bold>1c</bold>)

A mixture of [MoO2(acac)2] (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) and H2LH·H2O (0.08 g, 0.31 mmol) in methanol (25 mL) was heated under reflux for 4 h. Yellow product was obtained. Yield: 102 mg, 83.3%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>4OMe</sup>)­(MeOH)] (<bold>3c-α</bold>)

Ligand H2L4OMe (0.085 g, 0.31 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of methanol. Acetanhydride (200 μL) was added to the solution and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The solution was cooled to 5 °C and [MoO2(acac)2] (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) was added. The suspension was transferred without stirring to the refrigerator and then left overnight. Red (α form) and yellow crystals (β form) were filtered and dried.

The reaction of H2L4OMe and [MoO2(acac)2] was repeated by the addition of seed crystals of α form. The suspension was transferred without stirring to the refrigerator and then left overnight. The obtained red precipitate was filtered and dried. Yield: 120 mg, 91.2%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>4OMe</sup>)­(MeOH)] (<bold>3c-β</bold>)

Complex 3b (0.05 g, 0.11 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (35 mL) and heated at 35–40 °C for 1 h. Then Et3N (20 μL) was added, and the mixture was heated for another 2 h. After several days, the product was filtered and dried. Yield: 10 mg, 20.21%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>H</sup>)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of [MoO2(acac)2] (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol), H2LH·H2O (0.08 g, 0.31 mmol), and ethanol (25 mL) was sealed in a 35 mL Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 110 °C in an oven for 2 h. The resulting solution was allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. The next day, the product was filtered and dried. Yield: 80 mg, 71.1%.

MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>3OMe</sup>)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of [MoO2(acac)2] (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) and H2L3OMe·H2O (0.09 g, 0.31 mmol) in methanol (20 mL) was heated under reflux for 1 h. The next day, the product was filtered and dried. Yield: 90 mg, 73.9%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>4OMe</sup>)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The complex was prepared in the same manner as 2 using [MoO2(acac)2] and H2L4OMe·H2O. Yield: 90 mg, 73.9%.

[MoO<sub>2</sub>(L<sup>4OMe</sup>)]<sub>4</sub>­·0.5MeCN (<bold>3′·0.5MeCN</bold>)

A mixture prepared by adding [MoO2(acac)2] (0.1 g, 0.31 mmol) to the solution of H2L4OMe·H2O (0.09 g, 0.31 mmol) in 135 mL of acetonitrile was heated at 50 °C for 3 h. The obtained product was filtered and dried. After filtration, the crystals for TG measurement were quickly transferred on a dry filter paper into a desiccator and then placed in a freezer (at −15 °C) in order to prevent loss of MeCN molecules. The sample for elemental analysis was completely desolvated until it was a constant weight and analyzed as 3′. Yield: 65 mg, 53.3%.

General Procedure for the Epoxidation of Cyclooctene by TBHP (in Water or Decane)

In a typical reaction, cyclooctene (2.76 mL, 20 mmol), aqueous TBHP (70% w/w, 40 mmol) or TBHP in decane (5.5 mol dm–3, 40 mmol) and acetophenone (0.1 mL) and molybdenum (pre)­catalyst, 1–3 or 3′ (0.05 mmol), were used, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 5 h at 80 °C. The reaction was monitored by withdrawing small aliquots at certain time intervals and analyzing them by GC.
